trends: There have been 2 other sightings in Somerset
There were no other sightings in Somerset on or around June 15th 2012
divs: Sighting DetailsJune 15, 2012 ��� Observation location is about 16 miles south of San Antonio, Texas on Highway 16 South. We did not have a GPS available but the Latitude and Longitude is close to this: 29.191807,-98.583584. This observation started at 9:45 PM Central Time and lasted until 12:05 AM. We used Night Vision Goggles (NVGs) and Meade Instruments Refractor Telescope. We are facing south and looking almost straight up to Saturn at 75 to 80 degrees from ground level. From this observation location, you will need to start looking at the lower left side of Saturn as it is in the night sky at 9:45 PM. The object comes active just after a commercial airliner passes from the north and flies south towards Laredo though the southern corridor. I have not been able to see the object before 9:45 PM. What you will be looking for is a small flash of light. Under unaided eyesight, the small flash of light is about two to four times the size of Saturn. With the NVGs, you can see it clear and see the object flash out into space as well as flash towards Earth. We have timed the intervals between flashes at 28 to 33 seconds under unaided conditions. With the telescope, we can see the object flash its light down to Earth and also see the object flashes out into space between the downward flash of light. We have verified the object is in a Geosynchronous orbit directly above the San Antonio���s air traffic controlled southern corridor however, at this time we have not contacted the ATC nor NASA for any kind of confirmation. Web research states - if this object is a real satellite in (GEO) orbit, it should be 35,786 km (22,000 miles) above us. If this is a satellite, why does it flash a light so bright from 22,000 miles up? Anyway, if you get a chance of a clear, moonless night, look up and see something cool.
Summary: South San Antonio Texas Nighly Sighting Anyone Can See.
